title: 104_hr1162
content: The Act titled "Deficit Reduction Lock-box Act of 1995" establishes a deficit reduction lock-box ledger under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The "Deficit Reduction Lock-box Act of 1995" establishes a ledger called the "Deficit Reduction Lock-box Ledger" under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The ledger is maintained by the Director of the Congressional Budget Office and is divided into entries for each subcommittee of the Committees on Appropriations. Each entry includes the House Lock-box Balance, Senate Lock-box Balance, and Joint House-Senate Lock-box Balance. Amounts credited to the ledger are only positive and are credited upon the engrossment of any appropriation bill by the House of Representatives and the Senate. The "Deficit Reduction Lock-box Act of 1995" establishes a ledger called the "Deficit Reduction Lock-box Ledger" under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The ledger is maintained by the Director of the Congressional Budget Office and is divided into entries for each subcommittee of the Committees on Appropriations. Each entry includes the House Lock-box Balance, Senate Lock-box Balance, and Joint House-Senate Lock-box Balance. Amounts credited to the ledger are only positive and are credited upon the engrossment of any appropriation bill by the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Director shall credit the applicable entry balance with amounts of new budget authority and outlays equal to reductions resulting from amendments agreed to by each House to that bill. Upon the engrossment of Senate amendments to any appropriation bill, the Director shall credit the Joint House-Senate Lock-box Balance with amounts of new budget authority and outlays based on specified calculations. The "Deficit Reduction Lock-box Act of 1995" establishes a ledger under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The ledger includes entries for each subcommittee of the Committees on Appropriations, with House Lock-box Balance, Senate Lock-box Balance, and Joint House-Senate Lock-box Balance. Amendments reported by the Senate Committee on Appropriations are considered part of the original text of the bill for calculating reductions in new budget authority and outlays. The term "appropriation bill" is defined broadly. The "Deficit Reduction Lock-box Act of 1995" establishes a ledger under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 for deficit reduction. During House consideration of appropriations bills, Members will have access to a running tally of amendments adopted reflecting budget authority changes. Additionally, there are provisions for downward adjustments of allocations and suballocations. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to adjust allocations for appropriation bills based on the most recent budget resolution. The revised levels of budget authority and outlays will be submitted to each House for printing in the Congressional Record. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to require downward adjustments in suballocations of new budget authority and outlays when adjustments are made to allocations. The revised suballocations will be submitted to each House for printing in the Congressional Record. SEC. 5 amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include up-to-date tabulation of ledger amounts. SEC. 6 involves downward adjustment of discretionary spending limits. The discretionary spending limits for new budget authority and outlays for any fiscal year shall be reduced by amounts set forth in the final regular appropriation bill or joint resolution making continuing appropriations. This reduction is based on the Joint House-Senate Lock-box Balances for that fiscal year. The bill or resolution must include a statement of law indicating the adjusted discretionary spending limit for new budget authority shall be reduced. The discretionary spending limits for new budget authority and outlays will be reduced by specified amounts in the final regular appropriation bill or continuing resolution. This adjustment, which includes a waiver of certain provisions, must be reflected in reports under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The effective date for the adjustments in the final regular appropriation bill or continuing resolution must be reflected in reports under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. This Act applies to appropriation bills for fiscal year 1996 onwards. For FY96 bills engrossed after August 4, 1995, certain duties must be carried out within 10 days of enactment. The Act applies to appropriation bills for fiscal year 1996 onwards, with duties to be carried out within 10 days of enactment for bills engrossed after August 4, 1995. The definition of an "appropriation bill" includes general or special bills, as well as supplemental, deficiency, or continuing appropriations. Attest: Clerk.
